content:
Trying to do some rather basic things with CSS like font sizing and background colors. Stymied because if I inspect the page and pick out existing classes, it sometimes works (and sometimes also styles parts of other pages I didn't intend, because flexible rows reuse class names?). But if I try to assign my own classes and style those, it's a hodgepodge of sometimes-yes, sometimes-no.

For example: I can name a persistent block with a class contact-block, and if I style that background I can get the color I want, but it doesn't style the margins. So I take that out and put a custom class into the row declaration in the layout template—and that doesn't work. I'm inspecting all of this in Chrome and Safari, and copy-pasting the selector tree out of the browser and into the CSS sheets, rebuilding cache each time, and whether my declarations show up appears to be entirely random. It seemed to work when I used l-colmd4 or some such that was generated by the layout template—but then that's also the name of the sidebar column elsewhere, and applying any kind of additional selectors took away the styling entirely in both places.

Note: I'm brushing up on my CSS in my off-hours, so I could be missing something simple, but I assumed using the selector from the bottom of the class tree would always work?

Unsure if this is related, but there's a typo in Basis skin.css at line 1241, an extraneous */ tag. Removing it automagically fixed my bottom row settings, but not other issues. (All of my css edits are at the end of the file.)

For example, this:

.events-block li {
    font-size: 80%;
}

.events-block h2 {
    font-size: 120%;
    font-weight: bold;
}

...properly styles the H2 in the events-block block, but not the li entries.

Ha, now I'm just amuse-frustrated. Changing the name of the class from events-block to upcoming-events-block made it work better, but now two classes with identical CSS show up completely differently on the page.

.upcoming-events-block {
    font-size: 80%;
}

.upcoming-events-block h2 {
    font-size: 120%;
    font-weight: bold;
}

.facetweets-block {
    font-size: 80%;
}

.facetweets-block h2 {
    font-size: 120%;
    font-weight: bold;
}

Screen-Shot-2020-05-07-at-1.13.32-AM.png

Hey @Jeff Porten, it's hard to help solve problems like this without seeing the actual page... Is it live? In the case of the last screenshot, it looks to me like the Facetweets block is getting two (or more) font-size changes applied, since it's smaller text. In other words, check to see if there's other CSS further down the inspector that's changing the font-size. If so, your

.facetweets-block {
    font-size: 80%;
}

will be making it smaller again.

The super-secret URL: https://www-dev4a.spusa.org/home

The fact that this is dev site "4A," and that is probably an undercount of the times I've burned down the architecture and rebuilt, is fueling my lack of patience, which I'm trying mightily to restrain here.
@BWPanda (Peter) I've replaced the 80% with 0.8 em, with no change to the result.
Ok, there's no other font-size changes, so the reason Facetweets is smaller is because the Upcoming Events block isn't being changed in that regard.
@BWPanda (Peter) If there's any other CSS getting into that cascade, it's not from me; I've commented out all the other ways I've tried to reskin that column.
@BWPanda (Peter) Interesting. Upcoming Events isn't being resized now, but five minutes ago it was smaller than the main content, and FaceTweets was smaller still.

Alright, I think I got it. Remember earlier when I pointed out an unclosed comment in line 1241? There were also unclosed parens and brackets there; cutting them out fixed the problems I'm looking at now. And then I spotted that the original Basis skin.css file is only 1236 lines long, so clearly this is something I must've pasted without noticing along the way.

PEBKAC again. Thanks for helping me find it.
Ha, I didn't do much, but you're welcome!
I like the PICNIC acronym better, since it's easier to remember :stuck_out_tongue_wink: ...but glad you sorted things @Jeff Porten
Maybe using rem will work more easily? It is relevant to the base font
@klonos PEBKAC sounds like the epithet I'm muttering to myself under my breath when I determine it's the problem....
